Package com.nickbenn.adventofcode.model

Interface Direction

All Known Implementing Classes:
CardinalDirection, PrincipalDirection
public interface Direction
Declares basic operations relevant to directions of travel. The main use cases for implementations of this class involve travel between grid/lattice locations—that is, from one MatrixLocation to another. However, while these operations (like those of MatrixLocation are integer-oriented, there is nothing that prevents their use without an underling two-dimensional array. For example, this class and MatrixLocation can be used in a Set or Map to help manage the logic of movement on a large—but sparse—lattice.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    int
    columnOffset()
    Returns the change in the column index (in a two-dimensional matrix or lattice) that will result from a single step in this direction.
    default boolean
    isHorizontal()
    Returns a flag indicating whether this direction is horizontal—that is, without any vertical component.
    default boolean
    isOblique()
    Returns a flag indicating whether this direction is slanted or diagonal—that is, it is neither horizontal nor vertical.
    default boolean
    isVertical()
    Returns a flag indicating whether this direction is vertical—that is, without any horizontal component.
    Direction
    nextClockwise()
    Returns a Direction instance representing the next direction (as defined in the implementing class) from this one, in the clockwise direction.
    Direction
    nextCounterClockwise()
    Returns a Direction instance representing the next direction (as defined in the implementing class) from this one, in the counterclockwise direction.
    Direction
    opposite()
    Returns a Direction instance in the opposite direction of this one.
    int
    rowOffset()
    Returns the change in the row index (in a two-dimensional matrix or lattice) that will result from a single step in this direction.

  • Method Details

    • rowOffset

      int rowOffset()
      Returns the change in the row index (in a two-dimensional matrix or lattice) that will result from a single step in this direction. Note that row indices increase when moving down and decrease with upward movement, as they conventionally do in two-dimensional array visualizations and computer graphics.

    • columnOffset

      int columnOffset()
      Returns the change in the column index (in a two-dimensional matrix or lattice) that will result from a single step in this direction. (Column indices increase when moving right and decrease with when moving left.)

    • opposite

      Direction opposite()
      Returns a Direction instance in the opposite direction of this one.

    • nextClockwise

      Direction nextClockwise()
      Returns a Direction instance representing the next direction (as defined in the implementing class) from this one, in the clockwise direction. For example, in an implementation for cardinal directions, the next direction clockwise from east is south.

    • nextCounterClockwise

      Direction nextCounterClockwise()
      Returns a Direction instance representing the next direction (as defined in the implementing class) from this one, in the counterclockwise direction. For example, in an implementation for cardinal directions, the next direction counterclockwise from east is north.

    • isVertical

      default boolean isVertical()
      Returns a flag indicating whether this direction is vertical—that is, without any horizontal component. It will always be the case that isVertical() == (columnOffset() == 0).

    • isHorizontal

      default boolean isHorizontal()
      Returns a flag indicating whether this direction is horizontal—that is, without any vertical component. It will always be the case that isHorizontal() == (rowOffset() == 0).

    • isOblique

      default boolean isOblique()
      Returns a flag indicating whether this direction is slanted or diagonal—that is, it is neither horizontal nor vertical. It will always be the case that isOblique() == (rowOffset() != 0 && columnOffset() != 0).
